text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 7142 or fax your request to (361) 7141.
ALL PAPERS

- Prime Minister Gyula Horn said at his regular monthly press conference that former finance minister Lajos Bokros did not give a full briefing to the cabinet ahead of the sale of Budapest Bank in December 1995.

- Lawyer Marta Tocsik is withdrawing the whole of her confession made to police last October, not just those parts affecting the Socialist Party's treasurer and a Free Democrat fundraisier, said her attorney. Meanwhile, Tamas Deutsch of the Young Democrats has convened a special session of the parliamentary commission investigating the case.

- Hospitals will be operated on a non-profit basis, and outpatient care could be privatised, said Csaba Laszlo, deputy state secretary at the Finance Ministry after the economic cabinet meeting yesterday.
- Electricite de France announced that it will sell half of its stake in Edasz to Germany's Bayernwerk AG.
VILAGGAZDASAG
- The presidium of the Socialist parliamentary group see a pension and health care reform as vital tasks in the remainder of the present cycle, said caucus leader Imre Szekeres.
- Plans for selling off the state's 60 percent share of the Hungarian oil and gas company MOL may be adjusted in light of an offer by the US company Tenneco Energy to buy the gas business of MOL.
- The final version of a tender inviting bids for two national terrestrial broadcast TV channels is published in the Cultural Gazette today.
- The State Privatisation and Holding Co may invite a qualifying tender for the sale of K&H Bank.
NEPSZABADSAG
- Tunisian Foreign Ministry State Secretary Said Ben Mustafa has opened talks at the Foreign Ministry.

- The Free Democrats executive body will conclude a two-day meeting today to discuss a nearly 200-page report on those goals and assignments laid down in the government programme that have been implemented and what lies ahead.
MAGYAR HIRLAP

- Foreign Ministry State Secretary Ferenc Somogyi said that he got the impression after talks with Austrial officials that they have the political will to support Hungary's EU accession, but he felt that problems of labour movement offer the clearest example of the close link between integration and bilateral ties.
- Representatives of the World Bank and the Ministry of Industry started negotiations yesterday on financing for the construction of two reserve power plants in Hungary.

- Erzsebet Pusztai of the People's Party said that her party will initiate an amendment to the social insurance law at the upcoming session of Parliament as the present act "forces decent entrepreneurs into the black economy".
- A total of 4.7 million guests spent 15.5 million guest nights in domestic hotels and commercial catering facilities between January and November last year.
- Graboplast had consolidated pre-tax profits of more than HUF 1.6 billion on sales of HUF 15-15.5 billion last year, preliminary estimates reveal.
NEPSZAVA
- This paper provides detailed data on 1996 inflation.
- The National Federation of Trade Bodies estimates that thousands of individual entrepreneurs have returned their licenses since early January because of growing tax burdens and other fees.
-- Budapest newsroom (361) 327 4040
